title: Quotation of the Day: Bettors Take a Chance as Atlantic City Opens Under a New Normal
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 3, 2020.
content: “Probably I shouldn’t be here. But it was good to get a shower, do my hair, put on my mask and come out.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Awash With New Development Along Newtown Creek
description: Long Island City and Greenpoint, two of the busiest real estate markets in the city, are the ones to watch in this post-Covid moment.
content: Long Island City and Greenpoint, two of the busiest real estate markets in the city, are the ones to watch in this post-Covid moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: FedEx Joins Push for Washington Redskins to Be Renamed
description: The shipping giant paid $205 million for the naming rights to FedEx Field under a sponsorship deal that began in 1999.
content: For more than two decades, FedEx’s name and corporate identity have been intertwined with one of the National Football League’s legacy franchises: the Washington Redskins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sasha von Oldershausen
title: Could New York Finally Become a Bike City?
description: A 102-year-old bicycle shop in Queens did big business during the Spanish flu, the Depression and the oil crisis of the 1970s. But the pandemic poses a new challenge for a new age.
content: It was an hour before closing on a Monday afternoon in May, and a crowd had formed outside a bike store, in Jamaica, Queens. The shop was letting in only a few customers at a time. A 9-year-old boy with glasses waited expectantly at the door. Three teenagers sat on their bikes to keep their friend, Chanel Burton, company while she bought one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Covid-19 Contact Tracer Spends Her Sundays
description: Kimberly Jocelyn is at her computer on the weekends, but she forces herself to take breaks for fresh air and video calls with friends.
content: Kimberly Jocelyn is a contract tracing supervisor with New York City Health and Hospitals Test & Trace Corps, which has, since May, employed more than 3,000 researchers, callers and field workers in an attempt to stop the spread of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: The #Vanlife Business Is Booming
description: Coronavirus is just a distant memory while zipping around in a several-hundred-thousand-dollar custom van on the open road.
content: I do not own a car or a house or even a bicycle. Nor am I prone to following Instagram trends. Yet for weeks I have had an obsession: getting rid of all my possessions, breaking the apartment lease, and moving with my dog and my girlfriend into a tricked-out van.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Lin-Manuel Miranda and Disney: Timeline of a Collaboration
description: Disney+ is streaming a live-capture film of “Hamilton.” It’s just the latest chapter in a deepening relationship between the company and the musical’s creator.
content: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s relationship with Disney started inauspiciously. He wrote a song on spec for a holiday show. The company rejected it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jules Feiffer on His Long, Varied Career
description: Feiffer talks about his new picture book and more, and Steve Inskeep discusses “Imperfect Union.”
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Bettors Gamble With Their Money, and the Virus, as Atlantic City Reopens
description: Masks were mandatory on the sprawling casino floors, and food, drinks and smoking were forbidden. But gamblers showed up.
content: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. — Terril Tate left his house an hour before dawn on Thursday to be one of the first players at a craps table when the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino reopened at 6 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding, Anna Schaverien and Jessica Anderson
title: News Quiz: Russia, Carl Reiner, Supreme Court
description: Did you follow the headlines this week?
content: Did you follow the headlines this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Are Rising Sharply, but Deaths Are Still Down
description: This seemingly counterintuitive trend might not last, experts said. But the nation can still learn from the decline.
content: After a minor late-spring lull, the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States is once again on the rise. States like Arizona, Florida and Texas are seeing some of their highest numbers to date, and as the nation hurtles further into summer, the surge shows few signs of stopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Margaret Morton, Photographer at Home With the Homeless, Dies at 71
description: For nearly two decades, she chronicled communities on the edge of society in elegant photographs that drew comparisons to the work of Jacob Riis.
content: From her apartment on East 10th Street in Manhattan, Margaret Morton had a front row view of the homeless encampments that engulfed Tompkins Square Park in the late 1980s. As she walked to work at Cooper Union, where she was a professor, she began to photograph these improvised structures, showing the ways people were moved to make themselves at home even when they had so little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Turkey Convicts Human Rights Activists on Terror Charges
description: The cases are part of a widespread effort to quash dissent in the country, which has seen dozens of activists put on trial after a failed 2016 coup attempt.
content: A Turkish court on Friday convicted four human rights activists of terrorism charges, including two former leaders of Amnesty International, as part of a broader crackdown on opposition voices in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: For Interracial Couples, Love is Allyship
description: Plus: For the love of emus.
content: In recent months, systemic racism, police brutality and discrimination against Black people in America have been catalysts for tough conversations, including between Black and white interracial couples. The tragic deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and countless others has led many interracial couples to prioritize open and honest conversations about how society treats them differently and why allyship and advocacy are essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott and Jill Cowan
title: Why Are Fireworks Going Off Every Night in California?
description: It’s unclear if the problem is worse this year but complaints are on the rise in parts of California.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: The Well Summer Workout Challenge
description: Jump start your fitness routine.
content: Welcome to the Well newsletter. Every Thursday, we email readers with news and advice about living well every day. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: What to Say When People Tell You Their Coronavirus Fears
description: Empathy over dismissive positivity.
content: The coronavirus won’t be going anywhere for a long time — and neither will our fears about it. Some states have begun to roll back plans to reopen their economies, and as infections increase, the United States is consistently setting daily records for confirmed cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Biden Supporters Are More Worried About the Health Risks of Voting
description: Could this tilt turnout in Trump’s direction and affect the election result?
content: Identifying likely voters is a challenge for pollsters in every election. This year, the coronavirus, mail voting and a surge in political engagement may make it even harder than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emily Cochrane
title: Immigration Officers Face Furloughs as Visa Applications Plunge
description: Nearly 70 percent of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services employees will be furloughed because the immigration processing fees that fund the agency have plummeted.
content: WASHINGTON — Three years of restrictive and sometimes draconian immigration policies have left families separated, applicants for visas stranded and would-be immigrants looking for alternative destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jimmy Harney
title: In Defense of My Emu Tattoo
description: Only twice have I felt a connection so strong that self-consciousness fell away. The first time was with an emu.
content: Getting a tattoo during a first date is a risky move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Meeting at Just the Right Time
description: Mallory Traughber and Jessica Matthews had their first date over ramen, and just a few months later, they were facing Stage 4 metastatic breast cancer together.
content: Mallory Traughber had been out planting trees as a volunteer all morning on the day that she and Jessica Matthews were to have their first date, in February 2018. So when she arrived at the ramen shop, she was ready for a beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Now Showing: A First Love That Stuck
description: Ariella Segal and Eli Shapiro met in 2009 when both were freshmen at N.Y.U.
content: When the coronavirus forced Ariella Segal and Eli Shapiro to move their May 24 wedding to July 5, a rehearsal dinner was no longer necessary. But they did need an oil change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: They Started With a First Kiss. The First Date Came Later.
description: Jess Seok and Gifford Brooks had a first date a few months after sharing a kiss. Many months later, he asked her to be his girlfriend.
content: While most couples have a first date, followed at some point by a first kiss, Jess Seok and Gifford Brooks did not. But they didn’t skip the kissing part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emily Cochrane
title: Immigration Officers Face Furloughs as Visa Applications Plunge
description: Nearly 70 percent of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services employees will be furloughed because the immigration processing fees that fund the agency have plummeted.
content: WASHINGTON — Three years of restrictive and sometimes draconian immigration policies have left families separated, applicants for visas stranded and would-be immigrants looking for alternative destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jimmy Harney
title: In Defense of My Emu Tattoo
description: Only twice have I felt a connection so strong that self-consciousness fell away. The first time was with an emu.
content: Getting a tattoo during a first date is a risky move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Critics Fear Amtrak Is Using Pandemic to Cut Service That Won’t Return
description: Members of Congress are angry that the rail agency is asking for more money while planning to lay off staff and reduce services. Smaller communities that rely on rail service could be badly hurt.
content: WASHINGTON — Amtrak has long wanted to cut back on long-distance train routes that span America’s heartland, but political pressure from Congress made it next to impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Biden Supporters Are More Worried About the Health Risks of Voting
description: Could this tilt turnout in Trump’s direction and affect the election result?
content: Identifying likely voters is a challenge for pollsters in every election. This year, the coronavirus, mail voting and a surge in political engagement may make it even harder than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Are Rising, Even as Death Rates Trend Down
description: At least five U.S. states set single-day records on Friday as the country’s daily infection report passed 50,000 again. President Trump, in a speech at Mount Rushmore, barely mentioned the pandemic.
content: After a minor late-spring lull, the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States is again on the rise. States like Arizona, Florida and Texas are seeing some of their highest numbers to date, and as the nation hurtles deeper into summer, the surge shows few signs of stopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt, Rukmini Callimachi and Adam Goldman
title: New Administration Memo Seeks to Foster Doubts About Suspected Russian Bounties
description: Criticized for its inaction, the Trump administration commissioned a new look at a months-old intelligence assessment. It emphasizes gaps.
content: A memo produced in recent days by the office of the nation’s top intelligence official acknowledged that the C.I.A. and top counterterrorism officials have assessed that Russia appears to have offered bounties to kill American and coalition troops in Afghanistan, but emphasized uncertainties and gaps in evidence, according to three officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman, Patricia Cohen and Rachel Chaundler
title: European Workers Draw Paychecks. American Workers Scrounge for Food.
description: In the pandemic, the United States has relied on expanded unemployment benefits, while European governments have subsidized wages, avoiding a surge in joblessness.
content: LONDON — In the southeast corner of Ireland, Brian Byrne’s event-planning business was confronting a calamity. It was the middle of March, and the coronavirus pandemic was nearing peak lethality. As the government barred gatherings like music festivals, his revenue disappeared, forcing him to consider laying off his four full-time workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Virus Surges in Arizona, but the Rodeo Goes On
description: A former state official called what has happened in Arizona “a story of missed opportunities.” Hospital beds in the state are filling up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Uses Mount Rushmore Speech to Deliver Divisive Culture War Message
description: Down in the polls and failing to control a raging pandemic, the president cast himself as waging battle against a “new far-left fascism” that imperils American values and seeks to erase history.
content: WASHINGTON — Standing in a packed amphitheater in front of Mount Rushmore for an Independence Day celebration, President Trump delivered a dark and divisive speech on Friday that cast his struggling effort to win a second term as a battle against a “new far-left fascism” seeking to wipe out the nation’s values and history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: How Safe Are Outdoor Gatherings?
description: With the virus raging in many parts of the country, new restrictions have left many wondering about the safety of a backyard barbecue or picnic.
content: Is it still safe to socialize outside?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Australia Faces its Own Reckoning Over Diversity in Media
description: The Black Lives Matter movement has inspired Australians to examine issues of race in our own country.
content: In the 1980s, my mother was a reporter in Melbourne, where much of her work focused on the Indigenous communities in Victoria. She recently told me about a time when she went to her editors at The Age and suggested that they actively seek out and recruit young Indigenous reporters because — while she felt she had earned the trust of her sources — their stories would be better told by people from that community. Hiring a more diverse staff, she explained, would be better for journalism and better for the newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: In June, Slower Sales and Price Reductions in New York City
description: The month’s biggest closing was an apartment on the 88th floor of One57 that was acquired for 41 percent below the original purchase price.
content: The pace of closings slowed in New York City during the month of June as the coronavirus took a toll on buying activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and David W. Chen
title: What the Coronavirus Has Done to New Development
description: The pandemic paused residential construction and stalled sales. Now developers in Long Island City and Greenpoint are scrambling to bounce back.
content: Skyline Tower, the 778-foot luxury condo building in Long Island City that looms over western Queens, was built to break records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The Mug Shot, a Crime Story Staple, Is Dropped by Some Newsrooms and Police
description: The San Francisco Police Department said it would no longer release mug shots because they reinforce racial biases, joining a growing movement by newspapers and broadcasters to curtail their use.
content: For more than a century, police departments and news organizations have worked together to disseminate photos of people after their arrest, often bleary-eyed and despondent, sometimes defiant and smiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Rinn
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Grand Designs’
description: It’s a bit like “The Great British Baking Show,” but in this series, the goal is to build dream homes, not frangipani and iced buns. It’s also deeply human.
content: These days, it’s easy to assume the internet will eventually put every TV show and movie worth watching in front of my eyes somehow. Even if it’s made very far away. All TV worth gorging works that way, I thought, right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 2 Officers Face Murder Charges After Using Taser on Man More Than 50 Times, Officials Say
description: Court records said that the “dangerous and unnecessary tasing” by two officers in Wilson, Okla., was a “substantial factor” in the death of Jared Lakey, 28, a year ago.
content: Two Oklahoma police officers have been charged with second-degree murder after they used Tasers more than 50 times on a man who later died, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: James Sherwood, Who Revived the Orient Express, Dies at 86
description: A multimillionaire by 36, he also bought Cipriani in Venice, the “21” Club in New York, Harry’s Bar in London and dozens of grand hotels.
content: Over his long, colorful life, the peripatetic James Sherwood seeded many businesses — container leasing, a London guidebook, ferries and riverboats, hotels and restaurants (like the “21” Club in New York and Harry’s Bar in London), an ice cream company, a magazine, fruit farms and a vineyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Brighten your weekend morning with Joanne Chang’s blueberry scones.
content: Good morning. There’s a little convenience store attached to the gas station down the street from where I stay and, if you get there early enough, just after the sun makes its appearance in the eastern sky, it’s possible to obtain one of the six or seven egg sandwiches the cashier makes every morning before unlocking the door. They sit on a shelf by the register, in front of a new plexiglass shield, hot in their foil jackets, soft and salty within, a $4 treat on a day that won’t yield many of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Giovanni Russonello
title: Kanye West Dips a Toe in the Moment, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Blackpink, Jorja Smith, Washed Out and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Colleges Face Rising Revolt by Professors
description: Most universities plan to bring students back to campus. But many of their teachers are concerned about joining them.
content: College students across the country have been warned that campus life will look drastically different in the fall, with temperature checks at academic buildings, masks in half-empty lecture halls and maybe no football games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: The tragic history of “I can’t breathe.” Why you can have a kid or a job right now, not both. How Brooklyn Drill went global. Farewell, Carl Reiner. And more.
content: Welcome to the weekend. If you are an American, you are most likely having a quieter July Fourth celebration than last year. If you’re in Britain, you might finally be able to have a pint at the pub. Whatever you are doing, take care and make some time for some fantastic journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: James Sherwood, Who Revived the Orient Express, Dies at 86
description: A multimillionaire by 36, he also bought Cipriani in Venice, the “21” Club in New York, Harry’s Bar in London and dozens of grand hotels.
content: Over his long, colorful life, the peripatetic James Sherwood seeded many businesses — container leasing, a London guidebook, ferries and riverboats, hotels and restaurants (like the “21” Club in New York and Harry’s Bar in London), an ice cream company, a magazine, fruit farms and a vineyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: One Brother Got DACA, One Didn’t. It Made All the Difference.
description: The Supreme Court ruled that DACA was improperly terminated, but will new applicants be allowed to enroll in the life-changing immigration program?
content: Jack Miralrio and his younger brother, Owen, were born in Mexico and brought to the United States illegally by their mother when they were little. Growing up, both enjoyed video games, soccer and building toy cars. Both excelled at school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Protesting U.S. Immigration Policies, Artists Aim for the Sky
description: This Independence Day, 70 artists are having messages of solidarity and defiance typed in the sky to highlight the plight of immigrants held in detention centers.
content: The Thunderbirds and Blue Angels that President Trump plans to send flying over the National Mall this Fourth of July will have some stiff competition from a group of 70 artists looking to spread their own messages across the nation’s skies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Hedge Fund’s Run at Tribune Publishing Ends With a New Board Seat
description: Journalists have been wary of Alden Global Capital, which is known for gutting newsrooms to eke out profits from struggling publications.
content: Alden Global Capital seemed in position this week to take control of Tribune Publishing, a move that would have enabled the New York hedge fund to merge the parent company of The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun with MediaNews Group, an Alden-owned newspaper chain, to create a new media giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Randall Williams
title: ‘My Body Is a Confederate Monument’: Slavery, Rape and Reframing the Past
description: Caroline Randall Williams discusses her essay that puts Black Southerners like her squarely at the heart of the debate.
content: When the Times published my essay, “You Want a Confederate Monument? My Body Is a Confederate Monument,” I hoped that it would open, or even change, some minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Washington and the N.F.L. Might Change the Redskins Name. Why Now?
description: The move toward changing a mascot name after decades of complaints underscores how America’s most popular sport has scrambled to keep up with shifts in public opinion.
content: By the time they take the field this fall — that’s assuming there is a season given the coronavirus pandemic — the National Football League team in Washington, D.C., might have a new nickname.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Coronavirus Leads Some Athletes to Opt Out, if They Can Afford It
description: The decision on whether to participate in restarting seasons is exposing the haves and have-nots of the sports world.
content: The resurging coronavirus has in many places exposed fault lines of class and privilege that allow those with means to escape high-risk environments, to put off work and to elide financial concerns in the interest of staying safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Washington Redskins’ Name Review Follows Years of Protest
description: Many find the name offensive, yet there has always been defiance from the team’s owners.
content: The Washington Redskins’ announcement Friday that they would begin “a thorough review of the team’s name” is a potential culmination to years of protest and defiance over a nickname that many Native Americans and other advocates for change consider deeply offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Their Book Club for Two
description: Sigrid Gabler and Manly Romero read to each other every night, even for five minutes.
content: Every time Sigrid Carrie Gabler sees a full moon it reminds her of her first date with Manly Lin Romero in January 2019 at the Quarter, a restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Washington and the N.F.L. Might Change the Redskins Name. Why Now?
description: The move toward changing a mascot name after decades of complaints underscores how America’s most popular sport has scrambled to keep up with shifts in public opinion.
content: By the time they take the field this fall — that’s assuming there is a season given the coronavirus pandemic — the National Football League team in Washington, D.C., might have a new nickname.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Symone Sanders Bet on Biden, and Herself
description: No one is telling her to wait her turn now.
content: WASHINGTON — Growing up in Omaha, Symone Sanders would sometimes assume the identity of an alter-ego character named “Donna Burns,” an imaginary TV personality who would repurpose hairbrushes or forks or pens (or whatever) to use as her microphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: ‘Free Again’: New Yorkers, Virus in Mind, Head Back to Their Beaches
description: Shorelines are finally open for swimming, but outbreaks across the country have given officials pause about the city’s wider reopening.
content: After more than a month of closed beaches — and pitched battles over access to the ocean — Rachel Thompson, a schoolteacher, finally frolicked in the surf at Rockaway Beach in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: England Drops Its Quarantine for Most Visitors, but Not Those From the U.S.
description: In a bid to salvage the summer tourist season, travelers from France, Italy, Spain and dozens of other nations no longer have to isolate for 14 days after arriving.
content: LONDON — England will drop its mandatory 14-day quarantine for visitors from more than 50 countries but leave the restrictions in place for travelers coming from the United States, deepening the isolation of America and delivering another rebuke to President Trump for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: ‘They Have Lost Control’: Why Minneapolis Burned
description: After George Floyd’s death, pent-up frustrations, provocateurs and inexperienced leadership led to mayhem for three nights.
content: Two days after George Floyd died, the police chief of Minneapolis called the mayor around dinnertime. He needed help. What had begun as peaceful protests outside the Third Police Precinct was turning into mayhem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Have Americans Warmed to Calls to ‘Defund the Police’?
description: As they learn more about it, voters have shown some receptiveness to the phrase, polling suggests. But they largely want to reinvest resources, not eliminate departments.
content: Just over a month ago, the term “defund the police” was almost entirely the domain of activists and academics. Now it’s a household phrase, with a huge majority of Americans telling pollsters they recognize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: How the Coronavirus Is Transforming July 4 in Los Angeles
description: While the camaraderie that comes from attending fireworks and tailgates will be absent, technology may help new traditions take hold.
content: LOS ANGELES — Fireworks have been lighting up night skies across America, despite normally being set off almost exclusively on July 4. Red, white, blue and bright, these low-impact pyrotechnics are to “America’s birthday” as quickly melting candles on a cake are to yours or mine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Gentlemen, Take Control of That Beard
description: Sure, the unkempt mountain-man look was easy to rationalize under lockdown, but now it’s time for a trim — at least.
content: If you’re one of many men who grew a pandemic beard because it seemed like less effort than shaving, it’s time to rethink that. Unless the look you’re going for is unkempt mountain man — which, OK, anything goes these days — beard care takes time and effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Secret Contracts Held a Surprise for Fiorentina’s New Owners
description: Rocco B. Commisso completed his purchase of an Italian team in record time. It was only after the closing that he learned an agent controlled the fate of some of the club’s top players.
content: When Rocco B. Commisso completed his purchase of the Italian soccer club A.C.F. Fiorentina last summer, he described the deal as the “quickest closing in soccer history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Tiffany May
title: What Hong Kong’s Pandemic Experience Taught Uber About Other Cities
description: The city was among the first to close and among the first to reopen. But Uber’s lessons there could be difficult to duplicate elsewhere.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — In late February, Uber executives were set to gather in San Francisco to form business plans for the year as the coronavirus steadily spread beyond China. While some executives who were initially invited had been told to stay home, the remaining few huddled at Uber’s headquarters to make plans for the inevitable pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: It’s Not a Snake, but Beware of Its Venomous Bite
description: Animals called caecilians may have been among the first vertebrates on land to lace their bites with venom.
content: If a worm and a snake had a slimy, scandalous love child, it might look something like a caecilian: a legless creature that’s actually neither worm nor snake, but a soil-dwelling amphibian found in tropics across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Hamilton’ Streams Today. Here’s How it Happened.
description: If you never got to see Lin-Manuel Miranda portray Alexander Hamilton on Broadway, this might be the next best thing.
content: If you never got to see Lin-Manuel Miranda portray Alexander Hamilton on Broadway, this might be the next best thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Lenora Fay Garfinkel, 90, Architect for Orthodox Jewish Communities, Dies
description: Ms. Garfinkel thrived in a field dominated by men, juggling a career while raising five children. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: We Got ‘Hamilton.’ Why Can’t We Stream Every Broadway Show?
description: Even in lockdown, it’s still hard to cut a streaming deal for a professional show. Here’s what viewers can expect, for now.
content: Marc Kirschner, the co-founder of Marquee TV, an arts-oriented streaming service that launched in February, gets the question all the time: “People have been asking us when we were going to have ‘Hamilton.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Tânio Mendonça, Brazilian Carnaval Samba Composer, Dies at 52
description: Mr. Mendonça, who wrote music for Rio’s spectacular annual parades, was one of many victims of the novel coronavirus within the world of Carnaval.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Santaniello
title: When a Farewell Season Was Wiped Out, the Outfield Became a Diner
description: This was supposed to be the Pawtucket Red Sox’s final season in Rhode Island before moving to Massachusetts. Without any games for fans to attend, the team got creative.
content: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — The long goodbye to McCoy Stadium began in August 2018, when the Class AAA Pawtucket Red Sox of the International League announced the franchise would be moving 50 minutes up Route 146 to Worcester, Mass., starting with the 2021 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Seriously, Just Wear Your Mask
description: This is not complicated, folks.
content: Wear a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: We Got ‘Hamilton.’ Why Can’t We Stream Every Broadway Show?
description: Even in lockdown, it’s still hard to cut a streaming deal for a professional show. Here’s what viewers can expect, for now.
content: Marc Kirschner, the co-founder of Marquee TV, an arts-oriented streaming service that launched in February, gets the question all the time: “People have been asking us when we were going to have ‘Hamilton.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Santaniello
title: When a Farewell Season Was Wiped Out, the Outfield Became a Diner
description: This was supposed to be the Pawtucket Red Sox’s final season in Rhode Island before moving to Massachusetts. Without any games for fans to attend, the team got creative.
content: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — The long goodbye to McCoy Stadium began in August 2018, when the Class AAA Pawtucket Red Sox of the International League announced the franchise would be moving 50 minutes up Route 146 to Worcester, Mass., starting with the 2021 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Seriously, Just Wear Your Mask
description: This is not complicated, folks.
content: Wear a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Coronavirus Cases Spike, Appeals to Wear a Mask
description: Readers discuss resistance to mask wearing and offer suggestions (a raffle?) to combat this.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lonnie Wheeler, 68, Dies; Helped Ballplayers Tell Their Stories
description: A longtime sportswriter, he collaborated with Hank Aaron, Bob Gibson and Mike Piazza on their autobiographies. “I was there,” he once said, “to make the subject more literary.”
content: Lonnie Wheeler, a sportswriter and columnist who collaborated with the Baseball Hall of Famers Hank Aaron, Bob Gibson and Mike Piazza on their autobiographies, died on June 9 in Cincinnati. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: For Maine Lobstermen, a Perfect Storm Threatens the Summer Season
description: The state’s lobster industry, already struggling before the virus, could be crippled as tourism dries up, leaving boatloads of crustaceans and no one to eat them.
content: OFF THE COAST OF MAINE — As he pulled alongside one of his lobster pots, marked by a red and yellow buoy on the Penobscot Bay, Mike Hutchings extracted and measured several of the crustaceans that would contribute to his 130-pound catch that day. It was a decent haul but his assessment of the fishing season was grim: “The worst it’s ever been.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Some Unexpected Survey Results
description: “I was enchanted by her writing,” said Clifford Peterson, who met Carol Ryan during planning for Ramapo College’s 50th anniversary celebration, “by the incredible life she lived, simply enchanted.”
content: The symphony of power tools conducted by men in hard hats still echoed in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains when Carol Ryan first arrived at the brand-new liberal arts college in Mahwah, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Students May Qualify for Special Jobless Benefits
description: While traditional unemployment insurance usually leaves out students, they may be eligible for federal pandemic aid. But some states don’t make it easy to get.
content: High school and college students whose summer jobs fell through because of the pandemic may qualify for jobless benefits under a special federal program. But getting the funds is harder in some states than in others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas
title: Mass Transit, and Cities, Could Grind to a Halt Without Federal Aid
description: Reviving subway and bus services helped bring back cities before. It can do so again.
content: As Congress plans another round of economic rescue, it will have to take a step that lawmakers from both parties have found distasteful for four decades: federal operating aid for mass transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Chu
title: A Supreme Court Win for Gay Rights, but Not in My Church
description: It still refuses to ordain me because of my sexuality. So why do I stay?
content: The greatest joys in life might be the unexpected ones. I’d put the Supreme Court’s recent decision in Bostock v. Clayton County in that category. Who expected the high court to affirm that Title VII protected L.G.B.T.Q. people from employment discrimination? And who expected Justice Neil Gorsuch to author such an opinion? It was a tremendous, surprising win for equality — and it was one that I instantly knew would barely matter for many of us who are pursuing work in Christian ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Donkeys, Elephants and a Samoyed Puppy
description: They might differ politically, but agreed on getting a Samoyed puppy after they got married.
content: Paul Ryan Dorsey noticed Ariel Holy Gordon in August 2015 as soon as she walked into the University of Michigan Alumni Club bar in Washington and then they stood next to each other glancing up now and then to watch the first football game of the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Duterte Signs Antiterrorism Bill in Philippines Despite Widespread Criticism
description: Human rights groups say the new law will give the police and military forces more powers to stifle dissent.
content: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte signed a contentious antiterrorism bill Friday aimed at combating Islamic militancy in the south, a measure that critics warned could lead to more widespread human rights abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Nyimas Laula
title: After Fighting Plastic in ‘Paradise Lost,’ Sisters Take On Climate Change
description: Melati and Isabel Wijsen began campaigning to reduce plastic waste in Bali seven years ago. Now 19 and 17, they say the pandemic shows that stark measures to protect the planet are possible.
content: SEMINYAK, Indonesia — It was trash season on Bali, the time of year when monsoon storms wash up tons of plastic debris onto the island’s beaches. It was also the time for two teenage sisters, Melati and Isabel Wijsen, to organize their annual island cleanup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saw Nang and Richard C. Paddock
title: ‘I Thought I Would Die’: Inside Myanmar’s Risky Pursuit of Jade
description: A survivor was swept away by a wave of mud and water after the wall of a mine collapsed on Thursday, killing at least 200 people.
content: MANDALAY, Myanmar — An ominous rumbling was the only warning the young jade miner had that something was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Replaces France’s Prime Minister in Bid to Reinvigorate His Government
description: President Emmanuel Macron is reshaping his cabinet, starting with the removal of his popular prime minister, in a bid to give his government a fresh start in the last stretch of his term.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron shuffled prime ministers on Friday, removing the most popular member of his government and a potential rival in a bid to get a fresh start in the wake of a coronavirus outbreak that has hit France hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson’s ‘Global Britain’: Inspired Vision or Wishful Thinking?
description: Post-Brexit Britain is going it alone at a time when globalization is in retreat. But a clash with China over Hong Kong has shown the limits of what it can do.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his pro-Brexit allies have long promised that once Britain broke free of the European Union, it could play a bold new role on the world stage — one they dubbed Global Britain. For a few days this week, it looked as if they were actually making good on that promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Severe Floods in China Leave Over 106 Dead or Missing
description: Unusually intense rainfall has swept away buildings and ruined homes in southern China, affecting about 15 million residents. More downpours are forecast for Saturday.
content: In the inland Chinese city of Yichang, the murky water ran waist-high, stranding people in their cars and turning streets into canals. Near the metropolis of Chongqing, angry torrents of water swept away country roads. The tourist town of Yangshuo experienced a cloudburst that an official called a once-in-two-centuries event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Niece Presses Case Against Effort to Bar Publication of Her Book
description: Mary Trump and her lawyer filed documents questioning the validity of the nondisclosure agreement she signed, saying it was based on fraud and was too broad to be enforced.
content: Mary L. Trump, whose pending tell-all memoir about her uncle President Trump has incited a court fight on the eve of publication, spoke out for the first time publicly about the battle, saying that her book has “deep national relevance” and that the legal contract the family has sought to use this month to stop its release was based on fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Hustler’s Game
description: Hal Moore opens the holiday weekend with a nifty puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Never get cocky, that’s my motto. There I was, speeding through Hal Moore’s lively crossword, and I was very nearly done. All I had left was the western middle section of the grid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 3, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday July 3, 2020.
content: An article on Wednesday about calls for the founding director of the Southern Foodways Alliance, John T. Edge, to resign referred imprecisely to the dinner series Brown in the South. It was a benefit for the Southern Foodways Alliance and included a dinner at the James Beard Foundation; it was not sponsored by the alliance and the James Beard Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Hong Kong, U.K. Domestic Violence, Jeffrey Epstein: Your Friday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Young Ahmed’ and ‘Hamilton’
description: The latest movie from Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne is on Criterion Channel. And a film of the Broadway musical “Hamilton” debuts on Disney+.
content: YOUNG AHMED (2020) Stream on Criterion Channel; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. A bespectacled Belgian teenager gets swept up by radicalism in this most recent film from the brothers Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne. The teenager, a 13-year-old named Ahmed (Idir Ben Addi), falls under the influence of an extremist imam (Othmane Moumen). As Ahmed grows apart from his family, his attention falls on his math tutor, Inès (Myriem Akheddiou) — a fixation that leads to catastrophe. “The plot may hinge on Ahmed’s actions and motivations,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, “but the film’s real drama revolves around a central moral and political conflict, between religious extremism and a humanist ethos that is more behavioral than doctrinal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Shanley
title: Reflecting on Summer Camp in Our Campless Summer
description: The letters my children and I used to send to and from camp were little shots of treasure, containing everything we would use to put our family back together at the end of summer.
content: During the normal school year, before my three children and I were confined to distance learning and lockdown measures, I structured my time faithfully, maintaining a life with a purpose entirely my own. My children worked hard to carve out that kind of space for themselves too, the way children should.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stoney Portis
title: I Watched My War Story Become a Movie
description: I witnessed the making of “The Outpost,” a film about the day my unit fought off 300 Taliban fighters who tried to overrun our camp in Afghanistan.
content: When I learned that my U.S. Army cavalry troop’s war story was being made into a major motion picture, I worried that a Hollywood account of the battle would be inaccurate. My soldiers and I had been sharing stories since Oct. 3, 2009, when our 53 cavalry scouts fought off more than 300 Taliban fighters bent on overrunning Combat Outpost Keating in Nuristan, Afghanistan. By all quantifiable metrics, my unit won the fight, but at a devastating cost: Eight soldiers died, 22 were wounded and our camp burned to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Christian Monterrosa
title: He Drove 3,000 Miles to Find a Pool and Ended Up in the Ocean
description: Rudy Garcia-Tolson is determined to make a fifth Paralympic team, even if he has to start at the bottom. Or on a surfboard.
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Garcia-Tolson’s first installment here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Splitting 5-4, Supreme Court Grants Alabama’s Request to Restore Voting Restrictions
description: State officials had asked the court to block a lower court’s order that eased photo ID and witness requirements for absentee voting during the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — By a 5-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court on Thursday blocked a trial judge’s order that would have made it easier for voters in three Alabama counties to use absentee ballots in this month’s primary runoff election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Our Supreme Court Correspondent on This Week’s Abortion Ruling
description: A Louisiana law that could have reduced the number of abortion clinics in the state to one was struck down on Monday. In an interview, Adam Liptak, who covers the court, provided context to the decision.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Playing Beethoven’s Piano Sonatas Changed How I Hear Them
description: Our chief classical critic took on the daunting Opus 110 in college, and now relishes risky recordings.
content: For my senior piano recital in college, encouraged by my teacher, I took on an ambitious program. I opened with an elaborate Haydn sonata and ended by pairing a Chopin nocturne with his teeming Ballade in G minor. I also played the first three of Schoenberg’s Five Piano Pieces — intensely complex, atonal works that hooked me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Career Spent on Twitter Can’t Ever Tell the Whole Story
description: Ryan Babel, one of the first high-profile soccer players to use social media, has spent his career being defined by everything but his play.
content: If you are enjoying this newsletter every Friday, we’re glad. Now please pass it on to a friend (or two) and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Rudolfo Anaya, a Father of Chicano Literature, Dies at 82
description: His coming-of-age novel “Bless Me, Ultima” reframed the way many in New Mexico viewed their own history, even as school districts tried to ban it.
content: Rudolfo Anaya, a writer whose trailblazing explorations of the folkways of the Southwest helped define the Latino experience in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Albuquerque. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: A Beverly Hills Hotel, Bought With Looted Money, Goes on Sale
description: The Viceroy L’Ermitage Beverly Hills was owned by a fugitive financier involved in a $2.5 billion fraud. Interested? It’ll cost north of $100 million.
content: For sale: Boutique hotel, convenient to Hollywood. 116 rooms, rooftop pool, jet-setting clientele. Previous owner spent $40 million on renovations before becoming an international fugitive. Asking price: $100+ million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: The Mystery of High Stock Prices
description: Why is the market doing so well when the economy is doing so poorly?
content: From the Department of Curiosities: On Tuesday, as the number of new coronavirus cases continued to spike to record levels, the stock market closed out its strongest quarter in more than two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge Ramos
title: A Hard Conversation for the Latino Community
description: Racism is deeply rooted in America’s social system, putting Afro-Latinos at a constant disadvantage.
content: MIAMI — Every weeknight, I sit down next to my co-anchor Ilia Calderón to host the Spanish-language news program “Noticiero Univision.” Although our many viewers have come to know Ms. Calderón’s face, not many know how much she has had to overcome to sit in that chair. Her story, like that of many Latinos with African ancestry in the United States, is one of tremendous personal achievement, as well as astonishing perseverance in the face of deep-seated racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurence J. Kotlikoff and Michael Mina
title: A Cheap, Simple Way to Control the Coronavirus
description: With easy-to-use tests, everyone can check themselves every day.
content: Simple at-home tests for the coronavirus, some that involve spitting into a small tube of solution, could be the key to expanding testing and impeding the spread of the pandemic. The Food and Drug Administration should encourage their development and then fast track approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Denies Paying Bounties, but Some Say the U.S. Had It Coming
description: Russia’s grievances against what it sees as American bullying and expansion into its own zones of influence have been stacking up for decades.
content: MOSCOW — Three years into a grinding war in eastern Ukraine, the Trump administration, in a sharp break with Obama-era policy, proposed providing the Ukrainian army with potent American weapons, Javelin anti-tank missiles, to aid its struggle with Russian-backed separatists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Frederick Douglass, Seen Up Close
description: Yale has acquired a renowned private collection relating to the abolitionist and orator, including rarely seen family scrapbooks that offer a window onto his complicated private life.
content: In 2006, the historian David Blight had just given a talk about Frederick Douglass in Savannah, Ga., when he was introduced to Walter Evans, a retired surgeon and collector. Dr. Evans invited him to stop by the house and see his Douglass collection. Dr. Blight was cautiously intrigued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George E. Lewis
title: Lifting the Cone of Silence From Black Composers
description: Listen to how artists have explored what it means — and could mean — to be American.
content: A cone of silence hangs over the work of Black composers from Africa and its diaspora. It is not that Black men and women have not written music, but too often it has been ignored — and thus assumed not to exist at all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ashamed on the Fourth of July
description: A reader explains why she won’t be celebrating this year. Also: Skip the emails and pick up a pen.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Quoctrung Bui and Jugal K. Patel
title: Black Lives Matter May Be the Largest Movement in U.S. History
description: Recent polls suggest that about 15 million to 26 million people in the U.S. have participated in recent protests.
content: Recent polls suggest that about 15 million to 26 million people in the U.S. have participated in recent protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Reading Orwell for the Fourth of July
description: As we celebrate freedom, speaking freely is in danger.
content: This Fourth of July, it’s worth taking stock of the state of freedom — and of our attitudes toward it — at home and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurence J. Kotlikoff and Michael Mina
title: A Cheap, Simple Way to Control the Coronavirus
description: With easy-to-use tests, everyone can check themselves every day.
content: Simple at-home tests for the coronavirus, some that involve spitting into a small tube of solution, could be the key to expanding testing and impeding the spread of the pandemic. The Food and Drug Administration should encourage their development and then fast track approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Joyous Return to M.L.B.’s Ballparks, With a Dose of Wariness
description: “I know you can’t really see the smiles on us, because we’ve got our masks on,” the Red Sox’ manager said as teams were allowed to formally work out again. “But it was a long time at home.”
content: The quaint old emblem is everywhere at Fenway Park, from the Green Monster to the roofs of the dugouts to the exit ramps in the grandstand: two stockings, one snugly overlapping the other, the symbol of the Boston Red Sox for generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: She Felt Special by the Nikes He Wore
description: Lana Price had taken to approaching dating as a duty — one point for every date — and then she met Mel Wallace.
content: Lana Price was living in New York in 2015 and losing enthusiasm for dating when it struck her that she and her friends, who also reported lackluster attempts at romance, should try a new approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Don’t Call Him Machine Gun Kelly
description: The rapper and actor has a real name: Colson Baker. And he’s finding his voice during the lockdown.
content: A few days before Los Angeles announced a shelter-in-place order in March, Colson Baker, who raps under the name Machine Gun Kelly, sat down on a sofa with an acoustic guitar. His tattoos peeked through a white tank top. Tousled blond hair poked out of a Cleveland Cavaliers cap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pence Postponed Arizona Trip After Secret Service Agents Showed Signs of Virus
description: The agents’ conditions were among several virus-related factors that led the vice president to change his plans for a visit on Tuesday.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence postponed a planned trip this week to Arizona after Secret Service agents set to travel with him tested positive for the coronavirus or showed symptoms, two administration officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: WNYC Employees Demanded Diversity. They Got Another White Boss.
description: The public radio stalwart vowed to fix what its journalists said was a toxic work culture. But the latest changes have led to a newsroom revolt.
content: Three years ago, when the American workplace at long last began to clean house, sweeping away the vestiges of “Mad Men” habits, WNYC, the most popular public-radio station in the country, pushed three of its leading on-air personalities into the dust heap where so many bad men were piling up. A long period of turmoil and self-reflection followed, one that staff members referred to internally as the Troubles (“troubles with a capital T” as one producer put it to me, borrowing the phrase from the violent conflicts in Northern Ireland).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Latinos Back Black Lives Matter Protests. They Want Change for Themselves, Too.
description: Many Latinos are pushing for an acknowledgment of the systemic racism they face, and a conversation about over-policing in their own communities.
content: PHOENIX — “Tu lucha es mi lucha,” several signs declared at a recent Black Lives Matter protest near the Arizona State Capitol. Your struggle is my struggle. The sea of faces included young Latinos who had marched before, during the immigrant rights movement in the state a decade ago, when Joe Arpaio championed draconian policies as the sheriff of Maricopa County. There was no doubt in these protesters’ minds: Their fights against racism are bound up together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: As Neo-Nazis Seed Military Ranks, Germany Confronts ‘an Enemy Within’
description: After plastic explosives and Nazi memorabilia were found at an elite soldier’s home, Germany worries about a problem of far-right infiltration at the heart of its democracy.
content: CALW, Germany — As Germany emerged from its coronavirus lockdown in May, police commandos pulled up outside a rural property owned by a sergeant major in the special forces, the country’s most highly trained and secretive military unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Denies Paying Bounties, but Some Say the U.S. Had It Coming
description: Russia’s grievances against what it sees as American bullying and expansion into its own zones of influence have been stacking up for decades.
content: MOSCOW — Three years into a grinding war in eastern Ukraine, the Trump administration, in a sharp break with Obama-era policy, proposed providing the Ukrainian army with potent American weapons, Javelin anti-tank missiles, to aid its struggle with Russian-backed separatists.
source.name: The New York Times
